responses.gpt4:
One recommendation would be to follow a DASH diet, which stands for Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension. This diet is rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy foods. It also includes meat, fish, poultry, nuts, and beans, and is limited in sugar-sweetened foods and beverages, red meat, and added fats. This diet is not only good for people with hypertension but also provides benefits for people with kidney disease and diabetes. 

Moreover, limiting your sodium intake will also help protect your kidneys. Foods high in sodium include canned foods, certain dairy products, processed meats, and fast foods. Try to incorporate fresh foods and cook at home when possible.

Additionally, try to limit protein from animal sources and aim for plant-based proteins such as legumes, grains, and nuts where possible.

Remember, these are general guidelines. It's always a good idea to consult with a dietitian for personalized advice. Does this help answer your question, and do you have any other questions about your diet or anything else, Mr. Hardy?
